excellent: This is already really solid, but if you want to squeeze the last 1%, nudge each speaker forward by 1–2 cm. It slightly shifts how the room energises the low end and can flatten the last tiny bump without changing the core sound.

Try moving your listening spot forward or back by 10–20 cm. Sometimes an even flatter pocket sits just ahead or behind where you normally sit. When the bass suddenly feels more even, that’s the sweet spot.
Mark the current speaker positions on the floor. When peaks and dips are this well-controlled, keeping those exact spots saves you from undoing the good work accidentally.
good: Pull each speaker forward 5–10 cm. This usually knocks down small 80–150 Hz bumps caused by the wall behind them. It’s a simple move that often makes the bass noticeably cleaner.
Widen the speakers by about 3–5 cm each. This helps fix mild midrange dips created by the left and right outputs cancelling at your seat. If vocals feel clearer, you’ve nailed it.
Adjust toe-in by 2–3°. Small peaks can come from the tweeters pinging off the walls too hard. A tiny toe change smooths that out.
okay: Bring each speaker forward 10–20 cm. This helps break the bigger standing-wave lumps that cause obvious peaks. The next sweep should show a noticeably flatter bass region.
Move your listening position forward by 20–30 cm. If you’re sitting in a modal null, the bass disappears. Shift out of that zone and the low end comes back instantly.
Widen the speakers 5–10 cm. This usually cleans up upper-mid weirdness where both speakers interact. When done right, the sound opens up and loses that honky edge.
needs_work: Pull both speakers 25–40 cm from the wall. Big peaks won’t budge unless the speakers have room to breathe. This often smooths the worst bumps in one go.
Shift your listening position forward 30–60 cm. If bass is thin or patchy, you're almost definitely in a null. Moving out of it brings the missing bass straight back.
Try slight asymmetry — around 5–8 cm difference between left and right. Rooms often punish perfect symmetry with repeated peak/dip patterns. A small mismatch breaks the cycle.

good: Add something soft at the side-wall mirror points — a blanket, curtain or cushion. This knocks down early reflections without needing full treatment panels.
Increase toe-in slightly to focus more sound directly at you and less at the walls. This often trims the reflective bite in the upper mids.
Close or heavy up the curtains. A small change here can help tame a bit of slap echo.
okay: Put a rug or runner in front of the speakers to kill floor reflections. Hard floors throw loads of HF bounce straight at your ears.
Soften the side walls using anything textured — cushions, throws, a big plant. Doesn’t need to be proper acoustic panels.
Raise or lower the speakers by 2–4 cm if reflections seem mid-heavy. It adjusts the angle the HF arrives at your ears.
needs_work: Treat the first reflection points with something soft — rugs, curtains, a big sofa throw. You’re hearing too much room in the signal.
Move the speakers away from highly reflective surfaces like bare windows or corners. Square rooms and empty walls bounce everything.
If the room is really live, add one larger soft object (beanbag, blanket-covered chair, thicker curtain) near the side walls to take the edge off.
